Bodhisattva Deva was a person from South India. He was the disciple of NÄgÃ¢rjuna Bodhisattva and belonged to the Brahmin caste.
He was knowledgeable and had a profound grasp of things.
His talent and eloquence were unparalleled.
He was renowned in India and respected by all countries.
He searched through his mind and found nothing to be ashamed of.
He worried only that people would not believe his words.
In his country, there was a great deity.
A golden statue of him was cast, two zhang tall, sitting on a seat.
He was called the Great Self-Existent Heavenly Being.
If a person made a wish to him, he could make their current life go as they wished.
Deva went to the temple and asked to enter to pay homage to the deity.
The temple keeper said:
The heavenly image is extremely divine. People who see it dare not look directly at it.
Moreover, it causes people to lose their guard for a hundred days.
Why do you need to see it when you can just go ask for your wish?
Devadatta said, If the spirit can really do as you say, then let me see it.
If it cannot, how could it be what I want to see?
At that time, people admired his ambition and respected his clarity and correctness.
Tens of thousands of people followed him into the temple.
After Devadatta entered the temple,
the heavenly image shook and its eyes glared at him.
Devadatta asked, If it is a god, it should be great. Why is it so small?
It should awe people with its spiritual power and subdue them with its wisdom.
Yet it uses gold to adorn itself.
It moves crystal to deceive people. This is not what I expect.
He then climbed up the ladder and gouged out the eyes.
At that time, the onlookers all had doubts.
Why is the Great God of Freedom troubled by a small brahmin?
Is it not the case that his reputation exceeds his actual abilities and his reasoning is inadequate?
Devadatta explained to the crowd, The divine spirit is far-reaching and great.
Therefore, it uses recent events to test me.
I have obtained its heart, so I ascend the golden pile and emerge from the crystal.
Let you all know that the spirit does not rely on substance, and the essence does not depend on form.
Since I am not arrogant, the spirit is also not humiliated.
After saying this, he left.
That night he sought out the offerings and prepared them.ğŸ”½The next day, at dawn, he respectfully made offerings to the heavenly spirit.
Devadatta's name was already weighty, and moreover his wisdom penetrated the divine.
The words he spoke, wherever the sound reached, there was no lack of response.
In one night, the offerings and delicacies, whatever items were necessary, were all prepared.
The great god MaheÅ›vara held a piece of meat, several tens of feet tall.
His left eye was withered, and he came to sit.
He looked all around at the offerings and sighed in admiration, saying he had never seen such a thing before.
He praised his virtuous power, saying he was able to achieve something.
And he told him, You have obtained my heart.

People have obtained my form. You have offered your heart, people have offered their substance. Know that those who respect me, you fear them, and those who deceive me, people fear you. The offerings and delicacies you have prepared are all good and excellent.
Only those who can give what they see to those who need it are true givers.
Devadatta said, The spirit understands my mind. I will do as commanded.ğŸ”½The spirit said, What I lack is my left eye. If you can give it to me, then take it out.
Devadatta said, I respectfully follow the heavenly command. He then took out his left eye with his left hand and gave it to the spirit.
By the power of the spirit, the eye came out and grew back.
He continued to do this from dawn until noon, taking out tens of thousands of eyes.
The spirit praised him, saying,
Excellent, young man! You are a true giver.
What wish do you seek? It will surely be as you wish.
Devadatta said, I receive illumination from my mind, I do not need anything external.
I only regret that the ignorant masses
do not know to believe and accept my words.
If the spirit grants my wish, I must be allowed to make my words not empty.
This is all I request, I have no other needs.
The spirit said, It will surely be as you wish.
Then he left and went to NÄgÃ¢rjuna Bodhisattva.
He received the precepts of leaving the household life, shaved his head, and put on the Dharma robes. He traveled around teaching.
The king of South India ruled over the countries and believed in heretical paths.
Monks and disciples of the Buddha were not allowed to be seen.
People from far and near were all converted to his teachings.
Devadatta thought,
If a tree is not cut at the root, its branches will not be inclined.
If the ruler of a country is not transformed, the Way will not be practiced.
According to the laws of the country, the king's family provided money to hire people for guarding.
Devadatta then volunteered to be their leader.ğŸ”½Carrying a halberd, he led the way.
Arranging the ranks and leading the troops,
his authority was not strict but his orders were carried out.
His virtue was not apparent but people happily followed him.
The king was very pleased and asked, Who is this person?
The attendants replied, This person volunteered.
He does not eat rations nor does he take money,
yet in his duties he is respectful and his usual habits are like this.
We do not know what he seeks or desires.
The king summoned him and asked, Who are you?
He replied, I am a person of omniscience.
The king was greatly surprised and asked him,
saying, An omniscient person is a rare occurrence in the world.
How can you verify your claim?
He replied, If you want to know, wisdom lies in speech.
The king should ask me questions.
The king then thought to himself, I am a master of wisdom and a great debater.
Even if I can defeat him, it is not worthy of note.
If he does not perform as expected, it is no small matter.
If I do not ask him questions, it is a defeat for me.
He held his doubts for a long time.
Unable to do otherwise, he asked, What is the heavenly body doing now?
Devadatta said, The heavenly body is now engaged in battle with the asuras.
The king received this answer like a person who is choked and cannot either swallow or spit out.
He did not want to say it was not so, but had no way to verify it.
He wanted it to be so, but had no way to make it clear.
Before he could speak,
Devadatta said again,
This is not an empty discussion or a statement seeking victory.
O king, wait a little while and you will see the proof.
As soon as he finished speaking, weapons fell from the sky.
Long spears and short weapons were intertwined as they fell.
The king said, Although weapons are indeed used for war,
how do you know that this is a battle between the devas and asuras?
Devadatta said, Empty words are not as good as verifying them with real events.
As soon as he finished speaking, the fingers of the asura's hands and feet, as well as his ears and nose, fell from the sky.
The king then bowed his head and submitted to his Dharma and transformation.
In the palace there were ten thousand brahmins.
They all abandoned their topknots and received the precepts of accomplishment.
At that time, Devadatta established a high seat in the capital and set forth three treatises.
He said, Among all sages, the Buddha is the foremost.
Among all dharmas, the Buddha's Dharma is the most correct. Among all world-savers, the Buddha's Sangha is the foremost.
If there are debaters from the eight directions who can refute these words,
I will cut off my head to apologize for my defeat.
Why is this so?
To establish a principle but not understand it is foolishness.
The head of foolishness is not what I need.
I will cut it off to apologize for my defeat, and I do not begrudge it at all.
The debaters from the eight directions, having heard these words, also each came and gathered.
And they made a vow, saying:
If we are not as good, we will also cut off our heads.
The head of foolishness is also not begrudged.
Devadatta said, The Dharma I cultivate is to compassionately nourish all beings.
Those who insist on being defeated
will have their beards and hair shaved and become my disciples.
There is no need to cut off their heads.
Having made this vow, they each wrote down their names and principles and composed treatises with boundless arguments.
And they engaged in debate.
Those with shallow wisdom and short-sighted emotions were defeated with a single word.
Those with deep wisdom and far-sighted emotions went on for two days.
Then their words and principles were exhausted.
They all shaved their heads.
In this way, the royal family sent ten carts of robes and bowls every day, and after three months, more than a million people were ordained.
There was a disciple of a heretical path who was violent and foolish.
He was ashamed that his teacher had been defeated. Although he followed the assembly,
his mind was filled with resentment and hatred. He bit his knife and made a vow to himself.
You have defeated me with your mouth.
I will defeat you with my knife.
You have troubled me with your empty knife.
I will trouble you with my real knife.
Having made this vow, he hid a sharp knife and waited for an opportunity.
All the brilliant debaters from various directions had been defeated.
Then Deva went to a secluded forest,
composed the Hundred Treatise in twenty chapters,
and also composed the Four Hundred Treatise to refute wrong views.
His disciples each scattered under the trees to sit in meditation and contemplation.
Deva, having awakened from meditation, was walking back and forth.
The Brahmin disciple came to his side, held a knife to him, and said,
You have defeated my teacher with your mouth. How about I defeat your belly with my knife?
He then stabbed him with the knife. His five viscera fell to the ground, but he was not yet dead.
He pitied this foolish thief and told him,
I have three robes, a bowl, and a begging bowl on my seat. You can take them.
Quickly go up the mountain and do not go down to the level road.
My disciples who have not attained the forbearance of the nonarising of dharmas.
Will surely seize you or catch up with you and hand you over to the authorities.
The king will then trouble you. You have not attained the benefits of the Dharma.ğŸ”½Cherishing the body is of heavy concern, cherishing fame is next.
The body and fame are the source of suffering and entanglements.
Many faults arise from them.
The body and fame are the root of great suffering.
Foolish people without learning are invaded by false views.ğŸ”½They cherish what should not be cherished.
And do not cherish what should be cherished.
Is it not also pitiful?
I have received the Buddha's bequeathed Dharma and do not do so.
But I think of you all being deceived by the deluded mind.
Burned by anger and poison, the retribution of sins has not yet ended.
Weeping, we accept it.
Those who accept it are truly without a master.
Those who do it are truly without a person.
Those who are pitiful and cruel without a person and without a master.
Who can truly seek it?
In reality, it cannot be obtained.
Those who have not yet realized this
Are deluded by the crazy mind.
They are turned around by inverted views and become attached to the mind that obtains.
There is self, there are others, there is suffering, there is joy.
The coming of suffering and joy is only based on attachment.
If one understands attachment, there is no basis.
If there is no basis, there is no suffering.
If there is no suffering, there is no joy.
Since suffering and joy are both absent, it is almost extinguished.
After speaking these words, the disciples who had come earlier cried out loudly.
The disciples each gathered from the forests and trees.
Those who had not attained the Dharma-mind were frightened, wailing, beating their chests, and knocking their heads on the ground.
Alas! How cruel! Who has taken our teacher away like this?
Some ran wildly, chasing after the main road.
They divided up and chased after the cries, their voices echoing in the deep valleys.
Devadatta taught the people the truth of all dharmas.
Who is cruel? Who cuts? Who severs?
The reality of all dharmas is that there is no one who receives or is harmed.
Who is a friend, who is an enemy, who is a thief, who is a harm-doer?
You are deceived by the poison of delusion.
Falsely giving rise to views of attachment and crying out loudly, you create unwholesome karma.
What that person harms harms all karmic retributions, not me.
You should contemplate this and be careful not to chase after madness with madness, to grieve with sorrow.
Then he let go of his body, free and without pride, and finally left, shedding his slough. Since he first gouged out his eye and spirit, he finally had no eye.
At that time, people called him Kanthaka.
